copyright.text: Copyright 2018 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

titleText.ttltext: Herpes zoster burden in canadian provinces: A narrative review and comparison with Quebec provincial data

organizations: Institut National de Santé Publique du Québec

paras: Background. The main aim of this review was to assess incidence rates and trends of medically attended and death cases of herpes zoster in Canada. Methods. The search was conducted in five databases (@hit_startPubMed@hit_end, @hit_startCochrane@hit_end, @hit_startEmbase@hit_end, PsycNET, and Web of Science). Data on herpes zoster-related consultations and hospitalisations and deaths were also extracted from three Quebec provincial administrative databases (RAMQ, MED-ECHO, and ISQ). Results. The electronic search yielded 587 publications. Seventeen publications satisfied inclusion criteria. These publications reported data from eleven studies. Ten studies used provincial databases, and one study used the Canadian Primary Care Sentinel Surveillance Network electronic database. Seven studies evaluated overall rates of medically attended cases (consultations and hospitalisations). Four of these studies reported an increase in rates of medically attended cases during the study period; one study reported stable rates, and two studies reported only an average rate. The rates varied from 316 to 450/100,000 p.y. The Quebec @hit_startanalysis@hit_end shows similar rates with a slight decreasing trend (from 369 to 350/100,000 p.y.). Incidence rates of consultations were reported separately in three studies. Two studies reported an increase in rates (from 258 to 348/100,000 p.y. and from 324 to 366/100,000 p.y.), and the third study reported a decrease (from 525 to 479/100,000 p.y.). Hospitalization rates were reported separately in two studies, both reporting a decrease (from 12 to 8 cases/100,000 p.y. and from 9 to 4 cases/100,000 p.y.). Quebec data also showed a decrease, from 9 to 6 cases/100,000 p.y. One study reported herpes zoster-related deaths. In this study, the reported death rate was 0.7/1,000,000 p.y. in the overall population and 5.5/1,000,000 p.y. in those aged ≥65 years. Quebec @hit_startanalysis@hit_end showed a death rate of 1.2/1,000,000 p.y. in the overall population and 8.6/1,000,000 p.y. in those aged ≥65 years. Conclusions. The results of the reviewed studies and our @hit_startanalysis@hit_end of Quebec provincial data indicate important variations in the reported overall incidence rates of medically attended herpes zoster cases in Canada. The trends in time are heterogeneous in studies in which hospitalisations and medical consultations were pooled together. We observed a decrease in hospitalization rates and a slight increase in consultation rates in studies reporting hospitalisations and consultations separately. These results consolidate the understanding of the herpes zoster burden in Canada and might be used as a tool in decision-making regarding future preventive interventions.

titleText.ttltext: The cavd dataspace data sharing and discovery tool facilitates HIV immunological data exploration from pre-clinical and clinical HIV @hit_startvaccine@hit_end studies

paras: Background: The Collaboration for AIDS @hit_startVaccine@hit_end Discovery (CAVD) is an international research institution network whose primary mission is to accelerate the development of a safe and effective HIV @hit_startvaccine@hit_end. The DataSpace (dataspace.cavd.org) is an integral part of the CAVD's Global Access policy which requires public access to CAVD study data and information. DataSpace is a web-based, discovery tool developed to empower researchers by facilitating selfguided data exploration across a breadth of HIV @hit_startvaccine@hit_end study data. Methods: Currently, binding antibody, neutralization antibody, and cellular immunoassay results from over 186 @hit_startvaccine@hit_end products tested in 61 CAVD studies have been harmonized and are available for exploration and download. These data come from clinical trials, nonhuman primates studies, and studies in other animals. An application programming interface (API) for the R programming language is also available through the DataSpaceR package (https://github.com/ FredHutch/DataSpaceR). Results: We present three case studies demonstrating DataSpace functionality. First, we recreated published figures using the DataSpaceR API to illustrate DataSpace as a reproducibility tool. Second, we performed an adjuvant study power calculation to highlight study design utility. Lastly, we performed a @hit_startvaccine@hit_end durability @hit_startmeta@hit_end@hit_start-analysis@hit_end to feature metadata alignment across studies, a powerful feature of DataSpace. Conclusions: DataSpace is an invaluable tool for investigators to build upon HIV @hit_startvaccine@hit_end science by facilitating study design and @hit_startmetaanalysis@hit_end. Cross-assay or cross-study comparisons are streamlined as study data are quality controlled in a standardized format. For advanced statistical @hit_startanalysis@hit_end, our API provides access to statistical programming languages. As we demonstrated, access to metadata is made easy. For example, studies with complex schemas were easily aligned by @hit_startvaccination@hit_end time points to @hit_startanalyze@hit_end durability. DataSpace is continually growing, with 110 studies expected available by the end of 2018.

titleText.ttltext: Chemotherapy combined with dendritic cell @hit_startvaccine@hit_end and cytokine-induced killer cells in the treatment of colorectal carcinoma: A @hit_startmeta@hit_end@hit_start-analysis@hit_end

organizations: Department of Oncology, The Fifth Affiliated Hospital of Sun Yat-sen University

paras: Aim: To investigate the efficacy and safety of dendritic cell (DC) @hit_startvaccine@hit_end combined with cytokine-induced killer (CIK) cell therapy in colorectal carcinoma (CRC). Patients and methods: @hit_startPubMed@hit_end, @hit_startEmbase@hit_end, and @hit_startCochrane@hit_end Library databases were searched systematically for clinical trials of DC @hit_startvaccine@hit_end and CIK cell therapy combined with chemotherapy for CRC. The primary and secondary endpoints were overall survival (OS) and disease-free survival (DFS), respectively. Pooled risk ratios were used to assess the treatment efficacy. Both random and fixed effects models were used for statistical @hit_startanalysis@hit_end. The study population consisted of 871 CRC patients enrolled in four trials. Results: OS and DFS were significantly improved in patients who received chemotherapy combined with DC @hit_startvaccine@hit_end and CIK cells, and no severe adverse events were shown. Conclusions: The study demonstrated that the addition of DC @hit_startvaccine@hit_end and CIK cell therapy to chemotherapy is feasible and effective in patients with CRC.

titleText.ttltext: Efficacy and safety @hit_startanalysis@hit_end on dendritic cell-based @hit_startvaccine@hit_end@hit_start-treated@hit_end high-grade glioma patients: A @hit_startsystematic review@hit_end and @hit_startmeta@hit_end@hit_start-analysis@hit_end

organizations: Department of Experimental Medicine, Northern Hospital

paras: Background: Dendritic cell (DC)-based @hit_startvaccine@hit_end is a promising therapy for high-grade gliomas (HGGs); however, its actual effectiveness still remains controversial. This @hit_startmeta@hit_end@hit_start-analysis@hit_end aims to extensively evaluate the efficacy and safety of DC @hit_startvaccine@hit_end for HGG patients. Methods: We systematically searched @hit_startPubMed@hit_end, the @hit_startCochrane@hit_end Library, @hit_startEMBASE@hit_end, @hit_startMedline@hit_end, and Web of Science for relevant parallel randomized controlled trials (RCTs) and properly controlled non-randomized studies (NRS) published in English. Two investigators reviewed all the texts and extracted information regarding overall survival (OS), progression-free survival (PFS), and adverse events (AEs) from eligible studies. Sensitivity @hit_startanalyses@hit_end and subgroup @hit_startanalyses@hit_end were also conducted. Results: Of 353 suitable studies, 13 studies (three RCTs and ten NRS) involving 944 patients were finally included. Compared to the control therapy group (CT group), the DC group showed better OS and PFS without serious AEs. Subgroup @hit_startanalysis@hit_end showed that trials designed as NRS obtained better results in the DC group in this study; however, no specific subgroup regarding dosages, cycles or injection routes was found to be superior in the DC group compared to the CT group. Conclusion: DC @hit_startvaccine@hit_end can significantly improve OS and PFS, with acceptable toxicity, of HGG patients. Nevertheless, further studies are needed to verify this conclusion.

authorKeyword: Locally advanced and metastatic pancreatic adenocarcinoma

titleText.ttltext: First-line chemotherapy regimens for locally advanced and metastatic pancreatic adenocarcinoma: A Bayesian @hit_startanalysis@hit_end

organizations: Department of Pancreatic and Gastric Surgery, National Cancer Center/Cancer Hospital, Chinese Academy of Medical Sciences and Peking Union Medical College

paras: Background: Systemic chemotherapy is the standard treatment for locally advanced and metastatic pancreatic cancer, but there is no consensus on the optimum regimen. We aimed to compare and rank the locally advanced and metastatic pancreatic adenocarcinoma chemotherapy regimens evaluated in randomized controlled trials (RCTs) in the past 15 years. Materials and methods: @hit_startPubMed@hit_end, @hit_startEmbase@hit_end, @hit_startCochrane@hit_end Collaboration database, and ClinicalTrials.gov were searched for RCTs comparing chemotherapy regimens as first-line treatment for locally advanced and metastatic pancreatic adenocarcinomas. By using Bayesian network @hit_startmeta@hit_end@hit_start-analysis@hit_end, we compared and ranked all included chemotherapy regimens in terms of overall survival, progression-free survival, response rate, and hematological toxicity. Results: The @hit_startanalysis@hit_end included 68 RCTs, with 14,908 patients and 63 treatment strategies. For overall survival, NSC-631570 (hazard ratio [HR] vs gemcitabine monotherapy 0.44, 95% credible interval: 0.24–0.76) and gemcitabine+NSC-631570 (HR 0.45, 0.24–0.86) were the two top-ranked chemotherapy regimens. For progression-free survival, PEFG (cisplatin + epirubicin + fluorouracil + gemcitabine) ranked first (HR 0.51, 0.34–0.77). PG (gemcitabine + pemetrexed) (odds ratio [OR] 4.68, 2.24–9.64) and FLEC (fluorouracil + leucovorin + epirubicin + carboplatin) (OR 4.52, 1.14–24.00) were ranked the most hematologically toxic, with gastrazole having the least toxicity (OR 0.03, 0.00–0.46). Conclusion: The chemotherapy regimens NSC-631570 and gemcitabine+NSC-631570 were ranked the most efficacious for locally advanced and metastatic pancreatic adenocarcinomas in terms of overall survival, which warrants further confirmation in large-scale RCTs.

titleText.ttltext: The efficacy and safety of intravesical gemcitabine vs bacille calmette-guérin for adjuvant treatment of non-muscle invasive bladder cancer: A @hit_startmeta@hit_end@hit_start-analysis@hit_end

organizations: The First Affiliated Hospital, College of Medicine, Zhejiang University

paras: Objective: Several studies have compared the safety and efficacy of intravesical gemcitabine (Gem) with Bacille Calmette-Guérin (BCG) for non-muscle invasive bladder cancer. However, the results are not consistent. We carried out a @hit_startmeta@hit_end@hit_start-analysis@hit_end to provide a more comprehensive @hit_startanalysis@hit_end of the efficacy and safety of these 2 drugs. Methods: We searched @hit_startPubMed@hit_end, @hit_startEMBASE@hit_end, @hit_startCochrane@hit_end Library, Clinical Trials.gov, and reference lists. Randomized controlled trials and retrospective controlled trials comparing intravesical Gem and BCG in adjuvant therapy for non-muscle invasive bladder cancer published in English were included in this study. The strength of association was weighed by pooled risk ratio (RR) with 95% CIs. Sensitivity @hit_startanalysis@hit_end was performed to examine whether the findings of the @hit_startmeta@hit_end@hit_start-analysis@hit_end were robust. Results: We @hit_startanalyzed@hit_end 386 subjects from 5 pooled trials. Compared with BCG, intravesical Gem had lower incidence of dysuria (overall RR =0.31, 95% CI: 0.16, 0.61, I@sup_begin2@sup_end=0%, p=0.001) and hematuria (overall RR =0.27, 95% CI: 0.11, 0.71, I@sup_begin2@sup_end=0%, p=0.008). There were no statistical differences in risk of recurrence, progression, incidence of fever, and any adverse events between intravesical Gem and BCG therapy (p<0.05). No publication bias was found. Conclusion: This @hit_startmeta@hit_end@hit_start-analysis@hit_end suggests that intravesical Gem may have similar efficacy and lower incidence of dysuria and hematuria compared with BCG. Nevertheless, we recommend additional high-quality randomized controlled trials to confirm these results.

titleText.ttltext: @hit_startVaccination@hit_end and diabetes mellitus type 1 in children

paras: Influence of @hit_startvaccination@hit_end on the risk of developing diabetes mellitus type 1 (DM1) has been studied by different researchers for several decades. In rodents, @hit_startvaccination@hit_end can prevent development of DM1. This @hit_startreview@hit_end summarises existing @hit_startliterature@hit_end and discusses the results of a 2016 @hit_startmeta@hit_end@hit_start-analysis@hit_end, pertaining to @hit_startvaccination@hit_end and DM1. No @hit_startvaccines@hit_end appear to increase the risk of DM1. Additional investigations are needed to determine if @hit_startvaccines@hit_end can be considered protective against DM1. Patients with DM1 are at increased risk of morbidities from controllable infections. Children with DM1 should receive regularly-scheduled @hit_startvaccinations@hit_end; choice of @hit_startvaccines@hit_end and inoculation with non-regular @hit_startvaccines@hit_end should be determined on an individual basis. We present basic principles surrounding @hit_startvaccination@hit_end in patients with DM1 and @hit_startanalyse@hit_end the role of the paediatric endocrinologist in increasing @hit_startvaccination@hit_end uptake in children with DM1.

titleText.ttltext: Pentavalent antimonials combined with other therapeutic alternatives for the treatment of cutaneous and mucocutaneous leishmaniasis: A @hit_startsystematic review@hit_end

organizations: Medical Residency, Santa Casa de São Paulo, R. Dr. Cesário Mota Júnior

abstracts.publisherCopyright: © 2018 Taisa Rocha Navasconi Berbert et al.
paras: The first choice drugs for the treatment of cutaneous and mucocutaneous leishmaniasis are pentavalent antimonials, sodium stibogluconate, or meglumine antimoniate. However, the treatment with these drugs is expensive, can cause serious adverse effects, and is not always effective. The combination of two drugs by different routes or the combination of an alternative therapy with systemic therapy can increase the efficacy and decrease the collateral effects caused by the reference drugs. In this @hit_startsystematic review@hit_end we investigated publications that described a combination of nonconventional treatment for cutaneous and mucocutaneous with pentavalent antimonials. A @hit_startliterature review@hit_end was performed in the databases Web of Knowledge and @hit_startPubMed@hit_end in the period from 01st of December 2004 to 01st of June 2017, according to Prisma statement. Only clinical trials involving the treatment for cutaneous or mucocutaneous leishmaniasis, in English, and with available abstract were added. Other types of publications, such as reviews, case reports, comments to the editor, letters, interviews, guidelines, and errata, were excluded. Sixteen articles were selected and the pentavalent antimonials were administered in combination with pentoxifylline, granulocyte macrophage colony-stimulating factor, imiquimod, intralesional sodium stibogluconate, ketoconazole, silver-containing polyester dressing, lyophilized LEISH-F1 protein, cryotherapy, topical honey, and omeprazole. In general, the combined therapy resulted in high rates of clinical cure and when relapse or recurrence was reported, it was higher in the groups treated with pentavalent antimonials alone. The majority of the articles included in this review showed that cure rate ranged from 70 to 100% in patients treated with the combinations. Serious adverse effects were not observed in patients treated with drugs combination. The combination of other drugs or treatment modalities with pentavalent antimonials has proved to be effective for cutaneous and mucocutaneous leishmaniasis and for most seemed to be safe. However, new randomized, controlled, and multicentric clinical trials with more robust samples should be performed, especially the combination with immunomodulators.

titleText.ttltext: Prevalence of human papillomavirus type-16 in head and neck cancer among the Chinese population: A @hit_startmeta@hit_end@hit_start-analysis@hit_end

organizations: Henan Office for Cancer Control and Research, Affiliated Cancer Hospital of Zhengzhou University, Henan Cancer Hospital

abstracts.publisherCopyright: Copyright © 2018 Guo, Yang, Yin, Liu, Li, Zhang, Chen, Liu, Wang, Wang, Zhu, Lv, Wang and Sun. This is an open-access article distributed under the terms of the Creative Commons Attribution License (CC BY). The use, distribution or reproduction in other forums is permitted, provided the original author(s) and the copyright owner(s) are credited and that the original publication in this journal is cited, in accordance with accepted academic practice.
paras: Background: The burden of head and neck cancer in China is heavier, and studies have shown that it may be associated with HPV infection, especially high-risk HPV. Objectives: We aimed to conduct a @hit_startmeta@hit_end@hit_start-analysis@hit_end to estimate the high-risk HPV-16 prevalence of head and neck cancer in the Chinese population. Methods: The reports on HPV and head and neck cancer in a Chinese population published between Jan 1, 2006 and Oct 23, 2018 were retrieved via WANFANG/CNKI/@hit_startMEDLINE@hit_end/@hit_startEMBASE@hit_end databases. The pooled prevalence and corresponding 95% confidence intervals was calculated by a random-effect model. Results: The @hit_startmeta@hit_end@hit_start-analysis@hit_end included a total of 2,896 head and neck cancer cases from 28 studies. Overall, the pooled HPV-16 prevalence among head and neck cancer cases was 24.7% (20.2-29.3%) in China, 31.6% (21.7-41.5%) in oropharyngeal cancer, 28.5% (18.2-38.7%) in laryngeal cancer and 14.9% (10.1-19.7%) in oral cancer, 25.3% (14.8-35.8%) in fresh or frozen biopsies and 25.0% (19.5-30.5%) in paraffin-embedded fixed biopsies, 36.5% (17.9-55.1%) by E6/E7 region and 14.3% (6.4-22.1%) by L1 region of HPV gene. The highest HPV-16 prevalence was found in Central China. Conclusions: High prevalence of HPV-16 was found in the samples of Chinese head and neck cancers. Preventive HPV-@hit_startvaccination@hit_end may reduce the burden of HPV-related head and neck cancer in China.

titleText.ttltext: Progresses and perspectives of anti-PD-1/PD-L1 antibody therapy in head and neck cancers

organizations: Guanghua School of Stomatology, Hospital of Stomatology, Sun Yat-sen University

abstracts.publisherCopyright: Copyright © 2018 Yang, Liu, Qu, Liu, Zheng, Cheng and Sun.
paras: Head and neck cancer is the 6th most common malignancy worldwide and urgently requires novel therapy methods to change the situation of low 5-years survival rate and poor prognosis. Targeted therapy provides more precision, higher efficiency while lower adverse effects than traditional treatments like surgery, radiotherapy, and chemotherapy. Blockade of PD-1 pathway with antibodies against PD-1 or PD-L1 is such a typical targeted therapy which reconstitutes anti-tumor activity of T cell in treatments of cancers, especially those highly expressing PD-L1, including head and neck cancers. There are many clinical trials all over the world and FDA has approved anti-PD-1/PD-L1 drugs for head and neck cancers. However, with the time going, the dark side of this therapy has emerged, including some serious side effects and drug resistance. Novel materials like nanoparticles and combination therapy have been developed to improve the efficacy. At the same time, standards for evaluation of activity and safety are to be established for this new therapy. Here we provide a @hit_startsystematic review@hit_end with comprehensive depth on the application of anti-PD1/PD-L1 antibodies in head and neck cancer treatment: mechanism, drugs, clinical studies, influencing factors, adverse effects and managements, and the potential future developments.
